Award.AwardTitle: AstroGro STEM K-12 Education Program for I-Corps L

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Developed by a team of Caltech scientists and engineers, AstroGro is a NASA award-winning 3D-printed smart pod to grow fresh food in space. It is now being expanded into a project-based learning platform to revolutionize K-12 STEM education. Several states have adopted Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) to update K-12 STEM education. However, there is not only a deficit of tools and curriculum that will satisfy these new standards, but also a dearth of knowledge on how to teach STEM fields properly. While meeting these new standards, AstroGro technology is a platform for students to learn interdisciplinary skills (e.g. 3D printing, electrical engineering, computer programming, environmental sciences, and plant biology) and to also be enriched in core subjects (e.g. math, statistics, physics, and life sciences). Students will conduct hypothesis-driven testing and data-driven analysis through the AstroGro pod and platform which include a series of sensors that detect plant growth and its environment. The AstroGro platform also enables big-data science and the creation of citizen scientists at the K-12 level who will contribute to the big data. Not only will students learn about the real-world applications of their scientific contributions, they will further contribute to the solving of such issues. This project will involve the customer discovery process to determine viability of scaling and sustaining the educational applications of AstroGro.

The pedagogical knowledge for teaching project-based interdisciplinary learning will be developed. The learning combines cutting-edge technologies based upon NASA award-winning technology. More importantly, these teaching practices will be assessed through both formative and summative assessment. New assessment methodologies will be tested. Secondly, students will act as citizen scientists in determining plant optimality through the variation of growth conditions and growth measurement. This will produce an accessible data set for various species of plants. This will enable students to engage in scientific discovery. The information from the data set can be used for improving agricultural methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development found that found that US students rank 27thin math an 20thin science in a ranking of 34 countries. In response, several states have adopted Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) to update K-12 STEM education. However, there is not only a deficit of tools and curriculum that will satisfy these new standards, but also a dearth of knowledge on how to teach STEM fields properly.

While meeting these new standards, AstroGro technology is a platform for students to learn interdisciplinary skills (e.g. 3D printing, electrical engineering, computer programming, environmental sciences, and plant biology) and to also be enriched in core subjects (e.g. math, statistics, physics, and life sciences). Students will conduct hypothesis-driven testing and data-driven analysis through the AstroGro pod and platform which include a series of sensors that detect plant growth and its environment. 

 The AstroGro platform also enables big-data science and the creation of citizen scientists at the K-12 level who will contribute to the big data. Not only will students learn about the real-world applications of their scientific contributions, they will further contribute to the solving of such issues such as drought, sustainability, food literacy, and urban farming.

The intellectual merit of this project is two-fold. Firstly, pedagogical knowledge for teaching project-based interdisciplinary learning will be developed. The learning combines cutting-edge technologies based upon NASA award-winning technology. More importantly, these teaching practices will be assessed through both formative and summative assessment. New assessment methodologies will be tested.

Secondly, students will act as citizen scientists in determining plant optimality through the variation of growth conditions and growth measurement. This will produce an accessible data set for various species of plants. This will enable students to engage in scientific discovery. The information from the data set can be used for improving agricultural methods.

A typical end user is a K-12 teacher. The teacher is usually female (76%), with an average age of 43 years old [1]. Her science background can vary widely, usually depending on what grade and type of class she is teaching. For some teachers, using a spreadsheet program such as “Microsoft Excel” would be considered advanced, while other teachers have a laptop for every student.

 

With the rollout of the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS), a multi-state effort to create new education standards, teachers will need to transition “textbook learning” to 3-dimensional learning encompassing science and engineering practices, crosscutting concepts, and disciplinary core ideas. However, teachers face a dearth of quality instructional materials to address these new standards. In addition, the impending implementation of science assessments will create a large demand from schools to better prepare students for these standards.

 Unfortunately, K-12 teachers do not have many options for high-quality instructional materials. Currently, textbooks exist for teaching science and technology. However, NGSS is specifically designed to steer learning away from textbook learning. Some manufacturers have produced “manipulatives” kits to add a hands-on dimension to learning, but these are one-dimensional, have known outcomes and therefore are not true experimentation, lack engagement, and lack interdisciplinary learning. Other open-source curriculums exist for teaching science, but they are of low quality and require significant time commitments from the teacher to implement.

 Our innovation will empower teachers to train tomorrow’s citizen scientists, designers, and engineers through our cross disciplinary problem-based learning platform. Based on our NASA award-winning open-source project, AstroGro aims to:

(i) Use project-based active learning to help students piece explicit knowledge into tacit expertise in broad fields of STEM;

(ii) Combine cross-disciplinary fields in STEM through the use of cutting-edge technology to engineer for applications in science and real-world challenges;

(iii) Build scientific communication and collaboration within the classroom and between classrooms through a unifying unit  

[1] Feistritzer, C. E., Griffin, S., & Linnajarvi, A. (2011). Profile of teachers in the US, 2011(p. 9). Washington, DC: National Center for Education Information.
